strings:
<se_def>*: Oh, Marek! You are back!
It is so good to see you!
We were getting a little worried, you know.

<se_def>Marek: And worry you might! Would you believe,
I was attacked by a group of wolves!
And these people here came to my rescue.
<se_def>*: What terrible misfortune! But fortunate, of course, that you are now back safe and sound.
<se_def>*: My humble shop depends on you and your herbs, just as the rest of the town does.

<se_def>*: Hey hey hey! Marek the medicine man's back!
Wha's wrong!? Hic! Why the long face!?
Ha ha ha!
<se_def>Marek: Drunk again, I see. Do not expect sympathy when the next hangover comes.
<se_def>*: Don't be so cold! I thought we were <endash> Hic! <endash> friends! Go on, you big old bear, make me some o' tha' sober-up cocktail!
<se_def>Marek: I think the best medicine for you is not my herbs, but a headache that will make you think twice next time.
<se_def>*: HIC! Hold your huskies! Tha's not jus' cold, it's <endash> Hic! <endash> downright <endash> Hic! <endash> FREEZIN'! You leave me no choice! ...I mus' keep on drinking...

<se_low>*: Ah, Marek. I see you have returned.
How is the nook grass coming along?
<se_def>Marek: No luck, as usual. But someone was kind enough to give me a big bag of it.
<se_def>Marek: Now I will be able to help plenty of people who are suffering from the cold. This is just what I love about being a herb doctor.

<se_low>*: Well, well. That is good news.
I am glad to hear it.
<se_low>*: Marek normally has something of a shadow on his face, but today it is all lit up.
<se_low>*: Is it really the nook grass alone that has made him this way? Or is there perhaps some other reason?
